712975f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, north side, east from Madison Avenue, showing the Church of the Holy Trinity and the (1st) Grand Central Depot. The church, erected in 1873, was founded in 1864 by the younger Stephen H. Tyng. It has sacrilegiously been referred to as "The Church of the Holy Oilcloth."
The Grand Central Depot shown is the first to be erected on
this site and stood from 1871 to 1900.
About 1890
Gift of Urbrock Collection
N. w 274W

712976f-a.text:
42nd Street, south side, west from and including Madison Avenue, during the construction of the Interborough subway line. At the southwest conner of Fifth Avenue, in Bryant Park, the New York
Public Library may be seen under construction.
May 1, 1903.
NR(g W D720

712982f-a.text:
20-26 East 42nd Street (old numbers), at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue, the site of the future Union Carbide
Building, 40 East 42nd Street (new number).
1910.
Ewing Galloway.
Neg #2277

721318f.text:
42nd Street, north side, west from Madison Avenue. At the right is the Hotel Manhattan. This structure was later converted into an office building. It stands on the site of the old Draper home. In the center is the Bristol Hotel (with flag atop) located at the N. W. corner of Fifth Avenue. Silhouetted against the Times Bldg is the spire of a Presbyterian Church that faces Bryant Park. Note the "El" station at Sixth Avenue; the subway kiosks in the foreground and the electrified street car tracks.
About 1910
Ewing Galloway

712984f-a.text:
11-13 East 42nd Street, north side, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. 13 East 42nd Street, adjoining the Hotel Manhattan, will later be replaced by Schrafft's seven-story building.
About 1915.
Irving Underhill.

721324f.text:
Madison Avenue, north from 42nd Street. Old building on N.E. corner will be demolished in 1919 to make room for Liggett Drug Building. Manhattan Hotel, on N.W. corner will be remodelled in 1920-21. Tower of old St. Bartholomew's Church visible on S.W. corner of 44th Street, will be demolished in 1919-20. About 1921 Charles a Co's building on S.E. corner of 43rd Street will give place to Prudence Building. Covered subway entrances will go later.
Picture taken during street car strike of 1916.
Summer 1916.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.
ie. 54Nc A 771

721321f.text:
Madison Avenue, at northwest corner of 42nd Street, showing hotel Manhattan, remodelled into National City Bank Building
in 1921.
MAY BE REPRODUCED  1917 or 1918

730174f-a.title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - 5th Avenue.
730174f-a.text:
A general view of the midtown Manhattan Fifth Avenue zone above 42nd Street as photographed northward from the 25 story building at No. 309-13 Madison Avenue that adjoins the S. E. corner of 42nd Street. At the right margin appears the Charles & Co. Bldg. and the Hotel Biltmore. In the lower left corner is the rooftop of the Manhattan Hotel. This is shortly to become the National City Co. Bldg. The excavation in the foreground is for the Canadian Pacific Bldg. This site was formerly occupied by St. Bartholmews Church. The spires of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas and St. Patricks Cathedral indicate the line of Fifth Avenue.
1919
Gift of E.M.Jenks
James Suydam, photo
730174f-a.folder: 42nd Street and Madison Avenue, Manhattan, N.Y.

18 East 42nd Street, south side, between Madison and Fifth Aves., showing the Hallet and Davis Piano Company salesroom.

721323f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, at S.W. corner of 42nd Street, the Union Carbide Building.
On the N.W. corner the Hotel Manhattan is being altered into the National City Bank Building, and in the foreground construction is proceeding on the new Liggett Building.
1921.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.

712978f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, east from but not including Madison Ave., showing the Chrysler, News, Chanin and Lincoln Buildings at dusk. Across the backggPOund appears the East River and the Long Island City shore.

721322f.text:
Madison Avenue, south from E. 42nd Street, showing prominently the main office of Cushman and Wakefield Inc.;-occupying since 1927 the second floor of the Carbide and Carbon Building. This structure bears No. 30 E. 42nd Street and is at the southwest corner.
About 1928

712973f-a.text: Madison Avenue, East side and North east corner of 42nd Street, showing the P.E. Church of The Holy Trinity erected in 1873, since demolished account of business blocks.
